title: 107_s2633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy Act of 2002" or the "RAVE Act". Congress finds that many young people are introduced to drug culture at rave parties, which can vary in size and location. The trafficking and use of club drugs are prevalent in the rave culture, despite efforts by promoters to portray events as safe and alcohol-free. Despite efforts to portray raves as safe, promotional flyers with slang terms for Ecstasy or pictures of Ecstasy pills send a conflicting message to teenagers, promoting drug use. Rave promoters exploit American youth by facilitating drug use, knowing that Ecstasy causes users to become thirsty. Rave promoters profit from drug use at parties by selling overpriced water and items like glow sticks, oils, inhalers, and pacifiers to enhance drug effects. Ecstasy is the most popular club drug at raves, leading to many teenagers being treated for overdoses and health issues in emergency rooms. Ecstasy use has increased significantly in emergency visits, with mentions growing by 1,040 percent between 1994 and 1999. The drug damages neurons in the brain containing serotonin, leading to long-term brain damage even years after use. An Ecstasy overdose can result in increased heart rate, hypertension, renal failure, visual hallucinations, overheating of the body, and potentially fatal outcomes like heart attacks, strokes, and seizures. SEC. 3. OFFENSES. Amends Section 416(a) of the Controlled Substances Act to include managing or controlling any place for the purpose of unlawfully manufacturing, storing, distributing, or using a controlled substance. SEC. 416 of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse and Prevention Act of 1970 is about maintaining drug-involved premises. A conforming amendment was made to the table of contents. SEC. 4 introduces civil penalty and equitable relief for maintaining drug-involved premises. SEC. 4 introduces civil penalty and equitable relief for maintaining drug-involved premises, with penalties of up to $250,000 or 2 times the gross receipts from violations. Multiple violators may share the penalty, and violators are jointly liable. Additionally, violators are subject to declaratory and injunctive remedies as outlined in section 403(f). SEC. 5 amends the Controlled Substances Act to include section 416. SEC. 6 directs the Sentencing Commission to review and potentially increase penalties for offenses involving GHB. SEC. 7 authorizes appropriations for a Demand Reduction Coordinator. Authorization of $5,900,000 for hiring a special agent in each State as Demand Reduction Coordinator by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Authorization of appropriations for drug education to educate youth, parents, and interested adults about drugs associated with raves.
